In form they were equally varied—sometimes didactic, sometimes narra· tive, or dramatic, or epistolary; and they were written in a variety of metres. More than two ¹thirds, however, of the thirty books were in dactylic hexameters, which Lucilius appears to have finally settled upon as most suitable for his purpose; and this metre was used exclusively by his successors.
